result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

10:40 AM Defendant Rebecca M Bray in court with attorney Amanda Marie Nimmer.  Jack A. Pitzo appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

The Court conducts a colloquy with the Defense.
The Defendant requests a prelim hearing.
The Court conducts a hearing:

Officer Joshua Ledzian, of the City of New Berlin Police Department, sworn in and testifies on direct by ADA Pitzo.
Cross examination by attorney Nimmer.
The witness is excused and the State rests.
The Defense rests with no testimony proffered.
The Court deems testimony closed.

The State moves for bind over.
The Defense objects to bind over.
Court finds probable cause to believe that a felony was committed and binds the defendant over for trial.

Defendant to comply with I.D. Processing by close of business on Monday, May 9, 2022.  Defendant is ordered to report to the Criminal Traffic Division by close of business on Monday, May 9, 2022 to sign the signature bond.  Failure to do so shall result in the Court issuing a bench warrant.  Defendant to have no contact with Victim A listed in the Criminal Complaint/Victim Identification Key.  Defendant is not to share, reproduce or distribute any personal and/or identifying information about the crime victim(s), except to their attorney.
